data.title: Jamal Crawford wins NBA Sixth Man Award
data.meta_description: For a record third time, Los Angeles Clippers guard Jamal Crawford won the NBA Sixth Man Award. The 36-year-old Crawford re-established the record for the oldest winner.
data.text:
For a record third time, Los Angeles Clippers guard Jamal Crawford won the NBA Sixth Man Award. The 36-year-old Crawford re-established the record for the oldest winner. He was previously the oldest to win the award (34) two years ago. Crawford came off the bench in 74 of his 79 appearances and averaged 14.2 points and 2.3 assists in 26.9 minutes in all games, helping the Clippers (53-29) post their fourth straight 50-win season.

Nowitzki might miss Game 3

Dallas-Oklahoma series tied 1-1

Game 3: Thursday, 7 p.m. ET at Oklahoma

The Dallas Mavericks might be without franchise icon Dirk Nowitzki when they host the Oklahoma City Thunder in Thursday's Game 3 of the first-round series. Nowitzki was injured Monday and underwent an MRI exam on Tuesday that revealed he has a bone bruise in his right knee. It isn't yet known whether or not he can recover in time to play in the pivotal Game 3.â€‹

Watson earns full-time coach title in Phoenix

The Phoenix Suns removed the interim label off Earl Watson when they named him the team's head coach. Watson replaced Jeff Hornacek on Feb. 1 and went 9-24 over the final 2 1/2 months of the campaign. He received a three-year contract, according to a published report.

Kings looking at Clippers assistant Woodson for coaching job

The Sacramento Kings plan to interview Los Angeles Clippers assistant Mike Woodson for their head coaching vacancy, according to a report. The Kings received permission from the Clippers to speak with Woodson, Yahoo Sports reported. Sacramento is seeking a replacement for George Karl, who was fired after the season.

Mark Jackson in line for T-Wolves job

Former Golden State Warriors coach Mark Jackson will interview to become head coach of the Minnesota Timberwolves. Jackson, 51, was vital to building the current Warriors' roster and coached for three seasons before Steve Kerr took over prior to last season and won the 2015 NBA championship. Jackson was 121-109 with Golden State and involved in roster decisions but clashed with management.
